sideA: Las definiciones de los productos, como el SKU y la unidad de medida, se encuentran en una tabla maestra.

sideB.text: Product definitions, such as SKU and UOM, are found in a master table.
Item attributes like SKU and UOM are defined in the Master Item Organization table.
The Master Layer holds the product DNA, including SKU and UOM details.
Product definitions, such as SKU and UOM, are in a master table.

note:
[UOM] stands for Unit of Measure (Unit, Box, Kg, etc.).

[SKU] (Stock Keeping Unit) is the standard term for the product code.

sideA: Intento replicarlo yo mismo, o si me supera, lo escalo.

sideB.text: I try to replicate it myself, or if it's out of my depth, I escalate it.
I attempt to reproduce it, but if it's beyond my knowledge, I escalate.
I try to replicate it, and if it's too complex, I pass it up the chain.
I try to replicate it by myself, or if it is too much for me, I escalate it.

note:
[Out of my depth] is a great idiom meaning the situation is beyond your current capability or knowledge.

[Escalate] is the professional term for sending a ticket to a higher support tier.

~ ... or if it is to much for me... ~ (Incorrect spelling: 'to much' should be 'too much'.)

sideA: Yo diría: 'Gracias, revisando ahora. Te aviso en cuanto tenga novedades'.

sideB.text: I'd say: 'Thanks—checking now. I'll let you know as soon as I have an update.'
I would reply: 'Thanks, looking into it. I'll keep you posted.'
My response would be: 'Thanks. Checking now. I'll get back to you shortly.'

note:
[I'll keep you posted] is an excellent idiom for 'te mantendré informado'.

[As soon as I have an update] is standard professional phrasing.

~I'll let you know as soon as I get news.~ (Unnatural phrasing: In a professional context, use 'have an update' or 'hear back'. 'Get news' sounds like you are waiting for a broadcast.)

sideB.text: I need to understand the problem completely.
I need to fully grasp the issue.
I need to get a complete understanding of the problem.
I need to fully understand the problem.

note:
[Grasp] is a strong verb meaning to understand a complex concept fully.

[Issue] is often used interchangeably with 'problem' in IT.

sideA: No por mi parte, gracias. (Respuesta a '¿Alguna pregunta?')

sideB.text: No on my end, thank you.
None from me, thanks.
Nothing from my side, thank you.
Not on my end.

note:
Standard polite responses when asked "Do you have any questions?" in a meeting.

~No on my side.~ (Unnatural: Use 'None on my side' or 'Nothing on my side'. 'No' implies a vote.)

sideA: Si necesito más información, como pasos o capturas, le pregunto a quien reportó por Teams de inmediato.

sideB.text: If I need more info—like steps or screenshots—I ask the reporter on Teams right away.
If I require further details, such as reproduction steps, I contact the reporter immediately via Teams.
When I need more context, like screenshots, I reach out to the reporter on Teams instantly.
If I need more info—like steps or screenshots—I ask the one who reported it on Teams.

note:
[Reporter] refers to the person who created the ticket/bug report.

[Right away] or [Instantly] emphasizes your responsiveness.

sideB.text: Besides, explain something to me.
Also, please explain one thing to me.
Furthermore, explain something to me.

note:
**[114]**

Here, [Besides] acts as a connector meaning 'In addition' or 'Also'. It is followed by a comma.

~Besides, explain to me something.~ (Incorrect word order: In English, the object comes before the recipient. Say 'Explain something to me'.)

sideA: El stock real de los productos está en los almacenes físicos.

sideB.text: The real product stock is located in the physical warehouses.
Physical on-hand quantity is stored within the Inventory Organizations.
The actual inventory is managed at the warehouse level.
The real product stock is in the warehouses.

note:
In Oracle EBS terminology, 'warehouses' are often referred to as [Inventory Organizations].

[On-hand quantity] is the technical term for 'stock real' or 'existencias'.

sideA: Tomo la retroalimentación como una oportunidad para mejorar.

sideB.text: I take feedback as a chance to get better.
I view feedback as an opportunity to improve.
I see feedback as a way to grow professionally.
I take feedback as an opportunity to grow.

note:
[Chance] is slightly more casual than [Opportunity], but both are excellent here.

[To get better] is the most natural translation for 'mejorar' in a personal context.

sideB.text: I don't know if you have tested it yet.
I'm not sure if you've already tested it.
I don't know whether you have tested it or not.
I don't know if you tested it.

note:
This is an indirect question. Use standard sentence order [if you have tested], not question order ~if have you tested~.

Use [Yet] for negative/question contexts (ya/todavía) at the end of the sentence.

~I don't know if you tested yet?~ (Grammar: When using 'yet', it is better to use the present perfect 'have you tested yet'. If using simple past, you should include the object 'it', as in 'tested it'.)

sideA: Arreglé la query para que extraiga datos de Order Management.

sideB.text: I fixed the query so it pulls from Order Management.
I corrected the SQL to fetch data from the Order Management tables.
I adjusted the query to retrieve information from OM.
I fixed the query to get data from Order Management.
I fixed the query to retrieve data from Order Management.

note:
Verbs for data: [Pull], [Fetch], or [Retrieve].

[Fixed] implies repairing code that was broken or incorrect.

sideA: Ellos no dejaron documentación al respecto.

sideB.text: They didn't leave any documentation regarding this.
They left no documentation about it.
There is no documentation left on this matter.
They didn't leave any documentation about it.
They didn't leave documentation about it.

note:
[Regarding] is a professional alternative to 'about'.

~Regarding to this~ is incorrect. Never use 'to' after 'regarding'.

sideA: PL/SQL en EBS era mucho más profundo de lo que había visto; solo sabía lo básico de la universidad.

sideB.text: PL/SQL with EBS was way deeper than I'd seen—I only knew basics from school.
The PL/SQL in EBS was much more complex than what I learned in college.
EBS PL/SQL went far beyond the basic knowledge I had from school.
PL/SQL with EBS was much deeper than I thought — I only knew the basics from school.

note:
[Way deeper] is a common colloquial way to say 'much more complex/profound'.

~...than I saw...~ (Grammar: Use [than I had seen] (past perfect) to refer to the time before you started working with EBS.)

~...I only knew basics from school.~ (Grammar: You need the definite article 'the' before 'basics'. Correct: 'I only knew the basics'.)

sideA: Las definiciones de los productos (su ADN) y su stock están en tablas distintas.

sideB.text: Product definitions (their DNA) and their stock levels are stored in separate tables.
We separate the item master data from the physical on-hand quantities into different tables.
The Master Item table defines the product, while a different table tracks the physical inventory.
Product definitions (their DNA) and their stock are in different tables.

note:
[Master Data] (definitions) vs [Transactional Data] (stock levels) is a key concept in database design.

[Stored in] is the standard preposition for data in tables.
